8.79.text: When I came into the Tate

10.32.text: it was first of all a mad contrast from

15.26.text: I got such a sense of calm here.

19.50.text: This was one of the first photos I saw

23.44.text: the woman’s face just stayed in my mind.

26.58.text: I couldn’t remember the peripheral detail

36.26.text: I think what really resonated with me

43.50.text: the sense of recognition. I feel like I know her.

46.86.text: I feel like she knows me too.

49.30.text: I’m looking at the detail around it

50.84.text: looking at the fact that she’s holding a cigarette, that she’s almost smoked down

57.42.text: the fact that she’s sitting on the sidewalk and she doesn’t appear to be homeless.

62.00.text: It just sends me on this chase in my head about, causation, accountability, inequality.

72.48.text: I reacted to the piece, and a first line kind of occurred to me: how does it feel to be misperceived?

78.50.text: I start off analytically, posing a question to the woman.

81.98.text: But then something in her process strikes a chord with me. I then become her.

87.44.text: I get angry, and all of a sudden the poem has taken a different turn

91.30.text: I’m no longer the objective narrator

94.90.text: I’m now very much in the mix.

96.70.text: That sense of identification, I think, is what makes poetry, in my case, believable.

106.00.text: and this is my piece inspired by Paul Graham’s

113.36.text: How does it feel to be misperceived?

115.94.text: Does it justify the urge to disbelieve?

118.80.text: Because when you disbelieve you don’t have to expect

121.90.text: Which can help you accept what you have to accept.

127.44.text: And disappointments hurt, so you enjoy this avoidance.

130.50.text: All you have left is ‘I told you so’

133.24.text: By which time the relevance is as void as the point is.

136.62.text: You’re resistant to being pissed on for good

139.48.text: If you own the extent to which you are misunderstood.

142.24.text: So how does it feel to be misperceived?

144.72.text: It doesn’t feel like anything if you disbelieve.

148.78.text: But that doesn’t sound very appealing, though

151.34.text: Because at the end of the day

157.09.text: You trained yourself not to go there.

160.58.text: So you feel like you can’t change your world

162.82.text: So instead you trained yourself to change yourself.

165.50.text: Hopefully you benefit from the changes.

168.58.text: It’s actually quite clever, but it’s dangerous.

171.96.text: Because insecurity is not necessarily immaturity

174.92.text: It’s arguably the essence of your inner purity

178.20.text: Think about it, everything your heart has invested

181.38.text: Must be at least in part manifested

183.36.text: In the stack of the crap you bear off the back of the fact you care.

191.88.text: Because clearly within we’re just conforming

195.88.text: We’re not really living, we’re just performing.

198.26.text: Two notions we invent, pride and hope

200.32.text: But in reality, all of us consent by default.

206.12.text: It’s just why I can’t pretend that this community’s mine.

209.88.text: I’m not at the forefront of this community’s mind

213.82.text: just don’t feed me this community line.

216.16.text: I think I’ll just wait in this community line, and…

223.06.text: But either way, I’m too indifferent to you to be nervous.

229.84.text: My life could have been your life
